The Math

The math behind Invader generation is lightly discussed directly on the Invaders page, but Iâ€™ll go into detail here.

A helpful analogy for me was to picture this array of 15 as 15 switches next to eachother, each being switch on or off at random, until you have every possible combination. In simplist terms, this can be realized as a binary list of length 15.

Iâ€™ll admit, I struggled with how to do this correctly in Python. I jumped immediately to the itertools library, trying to work some magic with permutations and/or combinations, but Python kept thinking it should count each 0 in the list as unique, so I kept getting what I considered â€˜repeatâ€™ entries, for example: â€˜100000000000000â€™ and â€˜10000000000000â€™ - they of course appear identical to us, but Python was treating those separate 0â€™s as in a â€˜differentâ€™ order) Anyway, after lots of Google and Stackoverflow, it turns out that there is a simple on liner, which actually is the itertools library, just using a not-so-commonly seen method, product():

lInvaders = ["".join(seq) for seq in itertools.product("10", repeat=15)] # all binary combinations of 0s and 1s and length 15
